original_solution_mapping.L1: Each table takes 12 pieces of wood to make so 24 tables will take 24*12 = <<12*24=288>>288
original_solution_mapping.L2: There were originally 672 pieces of wood so now there are 672-288 = <<672-288=384>>384 pieces left
original_solution_mapping.L3: 8 pieces of wood make 1 chair so 384 pieces can make 384/8 = <<384/8=48>>48 chairs

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 4546.
    Returns: the number of chairs Gerald can make.
    """
    # L1
    pieces_per_table = 12 # 12 pieces of wood to make a table
    num_tables = 24 # if he makes 24 tables
    wood_for_tables = num_tables * pieces_per_table

    # L2
    total_wood_pieces = 672 # He has 672 pieces of wood
    remaining_wood = total_wood_pieces - wood_for_tables

    # L3
    pieces_per_chair = 8 # 8 pieces of wood to make a chair
    num_chairs = remaining_wood / pieces_per_chair

    # FA
    answer = num_chairs
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: Each table takes {pieces_per_table} pieces of wood to make so {num_tables} tables will take {num_tables}*{pieces_per_table} = <<{pieces_per_table}*{num_tables}={wood_for_tables}>>{wood_for_tables}

There were originally {total_wood_pieces} pieces of wood so now there are {total_wood_pieces}-{wood_for_tables} = <<{total_wood_pieces}-{wood_for_tables}={remaining_wood}>>{remaining_wood} pieces left
{pieces_per_chair} pieces of wood make 1 chair so {remaining_wood} pieces can make {remaining_wood}/{pieces_per_chair} = <<{remaining_wood}/{pieces_per_chair}={num_chairs}>>{num_chairs} chairs

flawed_nl_reconstruction.L1: Each table takes 12 pieces of wood to make so 24 tables will take 24*12 = <<12*24=288>>288
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L2: There were originally 672 pieces of wood so now there are 672-288 = <<672-288=960>>960 pieces left
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L3: 8 pieces of wood make 1 chair so 960 pieces can make 960/8 = <<960/8=120>>120 chairs

explanation: Incorrect operation. The calculation should use '-' but used '+' instead.
